article.description: BC handled Providence easily on Saturday.
article.headline: Friars held to 15 points in first half
article.linkText: BC stays hot, shuts down Providence
article.story: PROVIDENCE, R.I. (AP) -- Providence is struggling as it heads into tournament time. Jared Dudley had 15 points and eight rebounds and Boston College held the Friars (No. 13 ESPN/USA Today, No. 12 AP) to a season-low 15 first-half points to win 63-54 on Saturday and send PC to its second consecutive loss. "We played a little angry in the second half. That's what we need to do from the get-go," Providence coach Tim Welsh said, turning his attention to the Big East and NCAA tourneys. "If we don't do that, we're going to be one-and-done, one-and done." Craig Smith had 12 points and eight boards before fouling out with 2:55 left as BC (21-8, 10-6) won its fifth in a row and its eighth in its last nine games. Boston College could earn a first-round bye in the conference tournament if Syracuse loses to Connecticut and Seton Hall beats Rutgers in Sunday's games. "Hey, I love them," BC coach Al Skinner said of UConn, one of his team's biggest rivals. Providence (20-7, 11-5) will have a No. 3 seed and a bye in the tournament that starts on Wednesday. Providence star Ryan Gomes missed his first seven shots and finished with 13 points on 4-for-15 shooting, and the team shot just 19 percent in a dreadful first half. Donnie McGrath, who was scoreless against Pitt, had eight points and made 3-of-12 shots -- 1-for-8 from 3-point range. Providence was in position to win the conference title before losing to Pittsburgh at home on Tuesday. The Friars trailed Pitt by just seven points at the half before disintegrating in the second and losing 88-61. Considering that Pitt was ranked sixth in the nation, that one was understandable. This was harder to explain. "It still probably could have been in some guys' heads," Gomes said. "We tried to put some things behind us. maybe we did that only about 90 percent. We've got to regroup." Boston College is a likely NCAA Tournament invitee, but the Eagles had been 0-4 against ranked teams this season. They did beat N.C. State, which is now 16th but wasn't ranked when it played BC. "I think we're peaking at the right time," Dudley said. "We're just getting stronger right now." Skinner said his team's NCAA berth should be secure. "I think we're playing for a seed now," he said. "Any success we have in the Big East will help us." Of course, he said the same thing last year and the Eagles were one of the most surprising omissions from the 65-team field. With seeding in the Big East tournament at stake, Providence watched BC score the first 11 points of the game before Dwight Brewington tipped in a rebound with 13:11 left in the half. BC opened a 23-4 lead after 12 minutes and led by 20 points, 33-13, before Brewington scored with 38 seconds left in the first half. Providence mounted a 13-3 run to pull within six points, 40-34, midway through the second half. They stayed within range down the stretch but never got closer than that as BC, which did not make a basket in the final 4:59, hit 13 of 16 free throws down the stretch. Providence made just one of its first 11 shots and two of its first 16. The Friars had eight turnovers and trailed 23-4 before Marcus Douthit hit a basket with 7:48 left in the first and then converted the three-point play.
